message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, along with the presence of rhabditiform larvae in the stool, suggest a diagnosis of hookworm infection. A perianal serpiginous rash is a common manifestation of hookworm infection. Hematuria is not typically associated with hookworms, and peripheral lymphedema and muscle tenderness are associated with other diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss along with the presence of rhabditiform larvae in the stool suggests the patient has strongyloidiasis, which is caused by the parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercoralis. The perianal serpiginous rash is a characteristic finding in this condition. Hematuria is not typically associated with strongyloidiasis, while peripheral lymphedema and muscle tenderness are more commonly seen in other parasitic infections such as filariasis and trichinosis, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and stool microscopy suggest that the patient has a hookworm infection. Perianal serpiginous rash is a classic symptom of hookworm infection. Hematuria, peripheral lymphedema, and muscle tenderness are not commonly associated with hookworm infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of rhabditiform larvae suggests infection with Strongyloides stercoralis. A perianal serpiginous rash is a characteristic finding associated with this infection. Hematuria is not specifically associated with this infection, and peripheral lymphedema and muscle tenderness are not typical findings either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the stool microscopy suggest strongyloidiasis, a parasitic infection. Perianal serpiginous rash is a symptom commonly associated with strongyloidiasis. The other options are not typically associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of rhabditiform larvae suggests the patient has a parasitic infection, most likely Strongyloides stercoralis, which can cause perianal serpiginous rash. Hematuria, peripheral lymphedema, and muscle tenderness are not typically associated with this infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and stool microscopy suggest the patient has strongyloidiasis, which can cause a perianal serpiginous rash. Hematuria is more commonly associated with schistosomiasis, while peripheral lymphedema and muscle tenderness can be seen in filariasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss, along with the presence of rhabditiform larvae in the stool, suggest a diagnosis of hookworm infection. A perianal serpiginous rash is a common symptom of hookworm infection, caused by the larvae migrating through the skin. Hematuria is not a typical symptom of hookworm infection. Peripheral lymphedema may occur in filariasis, not hookworm infection. Muscle tenderness may occur in trichinosis, not hookworm infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and stool microscopy suggest strongyloidiasis, an infection caused by the parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercoralis. The perianal serpiginous rash is a characteristic cutaneous manifestation of disseminated strongyloidiasis. Hematuria, peripheral lymphedema, and muscle tenderness are not associated with strongyloidiasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of strongyloidiasis, which is caused by a parasitic infection of the roundworm Strongyloides stercoralis. The larval form of the parasite can cause a perianal serpiginous rash as it penetrates the skin, but none of the other options are associated with this condition.
